Award.AwardTitle: International Conference in Representations of Algebras (ICRA XIX)
Award.AbstractNarration: The Workshop and International Conference on Representations of Algebras (ICRA XIX) will be held at the International Centre for Theoretical Physics in Trieste, Italy, on July 21-31, 2020. This award will provide support for junior US based participants attending the meeting. The ICRA is an important biennial meeting in this subject that takes place every other year in countries all over the world. In 2016, the ICRA was held for the first time ever in the United States of America and has inspired many young researchers in the US to focus on representation theory of algebras and related topics. The meeting will consist of two parts: a four day workshop, and a five day conference. The workshop will have six speakers who each give a series of three lectures on a recent development in the field or a related area. The conference will consist in eighteen fifty-minute plenary lectures, in addition to a number of thirty-minute lectures which will be held in parallel sessions. The expected number of participants is two-hundred and fifty. The award will be used to support travel and lodging of US-based participants who are at an early stage of their career. <br/> <br/>Topics to be covered at the conference include quiver representations, Auslander-Reiten theory, homological properties, tilting theory, stability conditions and wall crossing, preprojective algebras, Hochschild cohomology, geometric methods in representation theory, cluster algebras, tensor categories, homological conjectures in commutative algebra, as well as methods from data analysis such as persistent homology. More information about the ICRA can be found at https://wiki.math.ntnu.no/icra2020/start.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award provided support for junior US-based researchers to participate in a major international conference in their research area: the 20-th iteration of the International Conference in Representations of Algebras (ICRA). 

The ICRA is an international conference series that takes place every other year in a different location. It is 'the' major event in representation theory of algebras. These conferences always have the same structure (a 4 day workshop with minicourses on current hot topics followed by a 5 day conference). The workshop was held on August 3-6 2022 in Montevideo, Uruguay and the conference on August 8-12, 2022, in Buenos Aires, Argentina. 

The workshop consisted of five minicourses held by Anna Barbieri (Padova), Karin Erdmann (Oxford), Julian Kuhlshammer (Uppsala), Rosanna Laking (Verona), and Hippolito Treffinger (Paris). The conference was a combination of parallel sessions and plenary talks. Keynote speakers were Nicolas Andruskiewitsch (Cordoba), Karin Baur (Leeds and Graz), Xiao Wu Chen (University of Science and Technology of China), Radha Kessar (London), Ivan Shestakov (Sao Pablo) and Bertrand Toen (Toulouse).

The purpose of the event is to dessiminate and discuss the state-of-the-art developments in the research area as well as to highlight connections to adjacent fields. It also serves as a meeting point where international specialists get together and discuss current and future projects. It is where many early career researchers get together for the first time with established researchers. 

The award supported ten junior US-based researchers to participate in the ICRA and three more to participate in the CIMPA school on Crossroads of geometry, representation theory and higher structures in Argentina in March 2023. In total, six graduates studends and seven early career researchers received funding for their travel. Five of the participants gave presentations at the events. 

Thereby the award provided a training and professional development opportunity for junior mathematicians from the US by funding their participating in a major international event in their field. The participation in an international conference often is a turning point in the career of a junior researcher. The project enabled thirteen junior researchers to live this experience.
